pages.title: Welcome to Phishing & Email Safety
pages.subtitle: Learn how phishing works and how to spot it before damage happens.

pages.title: What is phishing?
pages.text:
Phishing is a **social engineering attack** where someone pretends to be a trusted source to trick you into clicking a link, opening an attachment, or sharing sensitive information.

These messages are designed to look legitimate and often target people through email, text messages, or fake websites.

The goal is usually to steal passwords, deliver malware, or gain access to internal systems.

bullets.title: Phishing emails can look almost identical to real messages
bullets.text: Attackers often copy logos, tone, formatting, and even email signatures to appear legitimate.

bullets.title: Some phishing attacks use look-alike domains
bullets.text: For example, micr0soft.com instead of microsoft.com — a difference that’s easy to miss.

bullets.title: Business Email Compromise (BEC) is common
bullets.text: Attackers impersonate a boss or vendor to request money, wire transfers, or gift cards.

bullets.title: Urgency is a major red flag
bullets.text: Messages like "act now" or "final notice" are designed to pressure you into mistakes.

pages.title: Common phishing red flags
pages.text:
Most phishing attempts include warning signs if you know what to look for.

Be cautious of:

• Urgent or threatening language
• Requests for passwords or MFA codes
• Unexpected attachments or links
• Sender addresses that don’t quite match
• Messages that pressure you to act quickly

When in doubt, pause and verify before taking action.

pages.title: What to do if you spot phishing
pages.text:
If you believe a message is phishing:

1) **Do not click** links or open attachments
2) **Do not reply** to the message
3) **Report it** using your organization’s reporting process
4) **Delete the email** after reporting

Reporting helps protect not just you, but everyone in your organization.
